definition:
If $T$ is a theory of $\mathcal{L}$ then it is consistent iff there is
some model $\mathcal{M}$ of $\mathcal{L}$ such that
$\mathcal{M}\vDash T$. If a theory is not consistent then it is
inconsistent.

A slightly different definition is sometimes used, that $T$ is
consistent iff $T\not\vdash\bot$ (that is, as long as it does not prove
a contradiction). As long as the proof calculus used is sound and
complete, these two definitions are equivalent.
